uscom:FormParagraph.uscom:P: The present application, filed on or after March 16, 2013, is being examined under the first inventor to file provisions of the AIA.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: The drawings are objected to because:

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Many of the details shown in Figs. 5 and 10-11 are illegible because of the grayscale shading, in which many adjacent structures have similar shadings such that they are indistinguishable from each other.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: Many of the reference numbers in Figs. 3-11 are illegible because they are faintly shown.

Corrected drawing sheets in compliance with 37 CFR 1.121(d) are required in reply to the Office action to avoid abandonment of the application. Any amended replacement drawing sheet should include all of the figures appearing on the immediate prior version of the sheet, even if only one figure is being amended. The figure or figure number of an amended drawing should not be labeled as “amended.” If a drawing figure is to be canceled, the appropriate figure must be removed from the replacement sheet, and where necessary, the remaining figures must be renumbered and appropriate changes made to the brief description of the several views of the drawings for consistency. Additional replacement sheets may be necessary to show the renumbering of the remaining figures. Each drawing sheet submitted after the filing date of an application must be labeled in the top margin as either “Replacement Sheet” or “New Sheet” pursuant to 37 CFR 1.121(d). If the changes are not accepted by the examiner, the applicant will be notified and informed of any required corrective action in the next Office action. The objection to the drawings will not be held in abeyance.
The disclosure is objected to because of the following informalities:

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: It is suggested that the heading for the background be changed to “Background of the Invention” in accordance with MPEP 608.01(a).

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: It is suggested a “Brief Summary of the Invention” section be included in accordance with MPEP 608.01(a).
The following is a quotation of 35 U.S.C. 112(b):

uscom:P.uscom:Font: (b) CONCLUSION.—The specification shall conclude with one or more claims particularly pointing out and distinctly claiming the subject matter which the inventor or a joint inventor regards as the invention.

uscom:FormParagraph.uscom:P: The following is a quotation of 35 U.S.C. 112 (pre-AIA), second paragraph:

uscom:P.uscom:Font: The specification shall conclude with one or more claims particularly pointing out and distinctly claiming the subject matter which the applicant regards as his invention.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: Claims 6 and 17 are rejected under 35 U.S.C. 112(b) or 35 U.S.C. 112 (pre-AIA), second paragraph, as being indefinite for failing to particularly point out and distinctly claim the subject matter which the inventor or a joint inventor, or for pre-AIA the applicant regards as the invention.

Regarding claims 6 and 17, the term "about" renders the claim indefinite because the disclosure lacks any statement defining and limiting the term, such as a statement in the specification regarding a range of quantities associated with said term.

In the event the determination of the status of the application as subject to AIA 35 U.S.C. 102 and 103 (or as subject to pre-AIA 35 U.S.C. 102 and 103) is incorrect, any correction of the statutory basis for the rejection will not be considered a new ground of rejection if the prior art relied upon, and the rationale supporting the rejection, would be the same under either status.
The following is a quotation of the appropriate paragraphs of 35 U.S.C. 102 that form the basis for the rejections under this section made in this Office action:

uscom:P.uscom:Font: A person shall be entitled to a patent unless –

(a)(1) the claimed invention was patented, described in a printed publication, or in public use, on sale or otherwise available to the public before the effective filing date of the claimed invention.

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Regarding claim 1, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 a blowout preventer (“BOP”) for sealing against an object, comprising:

a housing (comprising body 12 and ring 38) comprising a bore (comprising the bore(s) passing between the bore 14 in the body 12 and the aligned bore in the ring 38, or the wider interior bore(s) of the housing comprising the interior wall 42 of ring 38 and the outer wall of the piston chamber 21) extending through the housing, the object being extendable through the bore; and

a packer assembly (comprising ring 48, annulus 52, and inserts 54) movably positioned within the housing and configured to form a seal within the housing (particularly with itself or with the object when the BOP is positioned to the closed position shown in Figs. 2 and 4, in a manner similar to the applicant’s packer assembly), the packer assembly comprising:
a body 48 comprising an elastomeric material (wherein the disclosure of a “resilient annular actuator ring 48” in col. 2, lines 56-57 is understood to mean an elastomeric material); and
an insert 52, 54 at least partially positioned within the body 48, the insert 52, 54 comprising:
a harder material section 54; and
a softer material section 52 with respect to the harder material section 54 and configured to deform against the object.

Regarding claim 2, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 that the harder material section 54 comprises a metallic material (col. 2, line 61) and the softer material section 52 comprises a non-metallic material (given that the softer material section 52 is described as being "resilient”).

Regarding claim 3, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 that the softer material section 52 comprises a tip (comprising the inner-most surface that seals against the object) that is positioned radially closer to an axis of the packer assembly than the harder material section 54.

Regarding claim 7, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 that the harder material section 54 and the softer material section 52 are connected to each other through an adhesive connection and/or a mechanical connection (particularly a mechanical connection wherein the harder material section 54 is embedded inside/surrounded by the softer material section 52).

Regarding claim 10, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 that the packer assembly is movable between an open position (Figs. 1 and 3) to allow fluid flow through the bore and a closed position (Figs. 2 and 4) to form the seal within the housing and prevent fluid flow through the bore (particularly when sealing against the object in the bore in the closed position shown in Figs. 2 and 4, as one having ordinary skill in the art would recognize).

Regarding claim 12, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 that the housing comprises an annular BOP housing (comprising body 12 and ring 38); and the body 48 comprises an annular body 48 positioned about the bore (comprising bore 14 in the body and the aligned bore in the ring 38) of the annular BOP housing.
Regarding claim 13, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 a packer assembly to form a seal within a blowout preventer (“BOP”), the packer assembly comprising:
an body 48 comprising an elastomeric material (wherein the disclosure of a “resilient annular actuator ring 48” in col. 2, lines 56-57 is understood to mean an elastomeric material);
an insert 52, 54 at least partially positioned within the body 48, the insert 52, 54 comprising:
a harder material section 54; and
a softer material section 52 with respect to the harder material section 54.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: Regarding claim 14, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 that the harder material section 54 comprises a metallic material (col. 2, line 61) and the softer material section 52 comprises a non-metallic material (given that the softer material section 52 is described as being "resilient”).

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Regarding claim 1, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 a blowout preventer (“BOP”) for sealing against an object, comprising:
a housing (comprising housing H-1 and alternatively including housing 52) comprising a bore 50 extending through the housing, the object being extendable through the bore; and
a packer assembly (comprising the nested sealing members 61, S) movably positioned within the housing and configured to form a seal within the housing (abstract), the packer assembly comprising:
a body 61 comprising an elastomeric material (wherein the disclosure of a “rubber or other suitable resilient material” in col. 5, lines 67-68 is understood to mean an elastomeric material); and
an insert at least partially positioned within the body 61, the insert comprising:
a harder material section (comprising any of the anti-extrusion structures 35, 36, connectors 40, and screws 66); and
a softer material section S with respect to the harder material section 61 and configured to deform against the object.

Regarding claim 4, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that there is a plurality of inserts (comprising the two semi-annular insert assemblies, including the sealing members S) at least partially positioned within the body 61, each of the plurality of inserts comprising a harder material section (comprising any of the anti-extrusion structures M, M’, connectors 40, and screws 66) and a softer material section S.

Regarding claim 5, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that the insert comprises a top support M, a bottom support M’, and a central support 40 extending between the top support M and the bottom support M’; the top support M comprises a top support harder material section 35/36 and a top support softer material section 36/35; and the bottom support M’ comprises a bottom support harder material section 36’/35’ and a bottom support softer material section 35’/36’ (wherein the support harder material sections and support softer material sections are broadly interpreted as names for structures that don’t necessarily compare the hardness of the structures with each other, and there isn’t any definite recitation comparing the hardness structures in claim 5, unlike the recitation in claim 1 comparing the harder and softer material sections).

Regarding claim 11, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that the housing comprises a cavity 50a (or 52a) intersecting the bore 50; the BOP further comprises a ram assembly (comprising ram carrier 60 and alternatively including plate 65) movably positionable within the cavity 50a and at least partially movable into the bore 50 of the housing; and the packer assembly is positioned upon the ram assembly to be movable with the ram assembly within the cavity 50a and form the seal at least partially about an object when the object is positioned within the bore 50 of the housing.
Regarding claim 13, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 a packer assembly to form a seal within a blowout preventer (“BOP”), the packer assembly comprising:
an body 61 comprising an elastomeric material (wherein the disclosure of a “rubber or other suitable resilient material” in col. 5, lines 67-68 is understood to mean an elastomeric material);
an insert at least partially positioned within the body 61, the insert comprising:
a harder material section (comprising any of the anti-extrusion structures M, M’, connectors 40, and screws 66); and
a softer material section S with respect to the harder material section.

Regarding claim 18, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that there is a plurality of inserts (comprising the two semi-annular insert assemblies, including the sealing members S) at least partially positioned within the body 61, each of the plurality of inserts comprising a harder material section (comprising any of the anti-extrusion structures M, M’, connectors 40, and screws 66) and a softer material section S.
Regarding claim 19, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that the body 61 comprises at least a semi-annular body formed about an axis (passing centrally through the bore 50, as shown in Fig. 8).

Regarding claim 20, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that the softer material section S comprises a tip (comprising the innermost surface) that is positioned radially closer to the axis than the harder material section 61 of the insert.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: Regarding claim 21, LeRouax discloses in Figs. 7-9 that the insert comprises a top support M, a bottom support M’, and a central support 40 extending between the top support M and the bottom support M’; the top support M comprises a top support harder material section 35/36 and a top support softer material section 36/35; and the bottom support M’ comprises a bottom support harder material section 36’/35’ and a bottom support softer material section 35’/36’ (wherein the support harder material sections and support softer material sections are broadly interpreted as names for structures that don’t necessarily compare the hardness of the structures with each other, and there isn’t any definite recitation comparing the hardness structures in claim 5, unlike the recitation in claim 1 comparing the harder and softer material sections).

In the event the determination of the status of the application as subject to AIA 35 U.S.C. 102 and 103 (or as subject to pre-AIA 35 U.S.C. 102 and 103) is incorrect, any correction of the statutory basis for the rejection will not be considered a new ground of rejection if the prior art relied upon, and the rationale supporting the rejection, would be the same under either status.
The following is a quotation of 35 U.S.C. 103 which forms the basis for all obviousness rejections set forth in this Office action:

uscom:P.uscom:Font: A patent for a claimed invention may not be obtained, notwithstanding that the claimed invention is not identically disclosed as set forth in section 102, if the differences between the claimed invention and the prior art are such that the claimed invention as a whole would have been obvious before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to a person having ordinary skill in the art to which the claimed invention pertains. Patentability shall not be negated by the manner in which the invention was made.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: This application currently names joint inventors. In considering patentability of the claims the examiner presumes that the subject matter of the various claims was commonly owned as of the effective filing date of the claimed invention(s) absent any evidence to the contrary. Applicant is advised of the obligation under 37 CFR 1.56 to point out the inventor and effective filing dates of each claim that was not commonly owned as of the effective filing date of the later invention in order for the examiner to consider the applicability of 35 U.S.C. 102(b)(2)(C) for any potential 35 U.S.C. 102(a)(2) prior art against the later invention.

uscom:LI.com:U: rejected under 35 U.S.C. 103 as being unpatentable over

uscom:GeneralText.com:U: Schaeper in view of Yenulis et al. (US 5,224,557)

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Regarding claims 1-3, 7, 10, and 12-14, Schaeper is seen as disclosing all of the limitations positively claimed, however, if the “resilient annular actuator ring 48” isn’t seen as being elastomeric, Yenulis teaches in Figs. 1-6 a BOP with a similar packer assembly comprising several nested resilient members 32, 38, 57 that are all elastomeric (col. 4, lines 42 and 52-53, and col. 5, line 44).

Therefore, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to make the body in Schaeper out of an elastomeric material, as Yenulis teaches with similar resilient members 32, 38, given that Schaeper is silent with regard to such detail. Furthermore, one having ordinary skill in the art would recognize that elastomers, like rubber, are readily available and provide the resilience necessary for the body.

Alternatively regarding claims 1-3, 7, 10, and 12-14, if the applicant isn't convinced that the packing assembly disclosed by Schaeper seals the housing in the closed position shown in Figs. 2 and 4, Yenulis teaches in Figs. 1-6 a similar BOP that is selectively transitioned into a closed position in which the packing assembly seals against the object 28 passing through the housing (abstract), and therefore seals the housing.

Therefore, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to have the packing assembly in Schaeper close at least against the object to prevent the leakage of fluid from the well, to prevent the object from moving during operation, and/or to prevent the object or fluid from being ejected from the well in a blowout (i.e. to prevent a blowout).

Regarding claim 2, Schaeper is seen as disclosing all of the limitations positively claimed, however, if the softer material section isn't seen as being non-metallic, Yenulis teaches in Figs. 1-6 a similar BOP comprising an insert comprising a softer material section 57 and a harder material section 85, wherein the softer material section 57 is non-metallic (specifically a elastomeric polymer as disclosed in col. 7, lines 40-43).

Therefore, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to have the softer material section disclosed by Schaeper be made of a non-metallic material, specifically an elastomeric polymer, as Yenulis teaches, since Schaeper is silent with regard to such detail. Furthermore, elastomeric polymers are readily available and provide the necessary resilience and sealing capabilities for the softer material section.

Regarding claim 8, Yenulis teaches in Figs. 1-6 that the softer material section 57 material comprises at least one of a plastic material, a glass fiber reinforced material, a multilayer material comprising a polymer and an inorganic material, a nanoparticle material, a polymer composite material, and another elastomeric material (specifically another elastomeric material in the form of a polymer as disclosed in col. 7, lines 40-43).

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: Regarding claim 15, Yenulis teaches in Figs. 1-6 that the softer material section 57 comprises at least one of a plastic material, a glass fiber reinforced material, a multilayer material comprising a polymer and an inorganic material, a nanoparticle material, a polymer composite material, another elastomeric material, and a metal (specifically another elastomeric material in the form of a polymer as disclosed in col. 7, lines 40-43).

uscom:LI.com:U: rejected under 35 U.S.C. 103 as being unpatentable over

uscom:GeneralText.com:U: Schaeper (alternatively in view of Yenulis) in view of Allen (US 4,099,699)

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Regarding claims 6 and 17, Schaeper discloses in Figs. 1-7 a softer material section 52 and an elastomeric body 48 (that is alternatively taught by Yenulis to be elastomeric), but Schaeper (and Yenulis) is silent with regard to the elastic modulus and hardness of the softer material section and elastomeric body, and therefore lacks teaching that the softer material section comprises an elastic modulus that is between about two to 100 times higher than that of the elastomeric material, and the softer material section 52 comprises a hardness that is at least five units (shore A) higher than that of the elastomeric material.

With regard to elastic modulus, Allen teaches in Figs. 1-3 a similar BOP comprising a softer material section 32 inserted within a resilient body 38, wherein the softer material section 32 comprises an elastic modulus higher than that of the resilient body 38 so that the resilient body 38 is more readily compressible to perform its intended function of constricting the softer material section 32 (col. 4, lines 3-19). Allen doesn’t disclose how much higher the elastic modulus of the softer material section 32 is relative to the resilient body 38, but Allen is seen as teaching an elastic modulus that is between about two to 100 higher because "about" renders the limitation broad and subjective.

Therefore, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to have the softer material section in Schaeper (alternatively including Yenulis) to have an higher elastic modulus than the elastomeric body, such as “about two to 100 times higher,” so that the elastomeric body is more readily compressible to perform its intended function of constricting the softer material section 32, as Allen teaches (col. 4, lines 3-19). The body transmits force to the softer material section solely by its compression, wherein the body doesn’t translate as a whole while the softer material section does when it is compressed by the body.

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: With regard to the hardness, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to have the softer material section in the combination of Schaeper and Allen (and alternatively including Yenulis) comprise any hardness higher than that of the elastomeric body, such as at least five units (shore A) higher than that of the elastomeric material, since hardness and elastic modulus are typically directly related such that one increases if the other is increased, and Allen teaches that the softer material section is designed to have a greater elastic modulus than the body (col. 4, lines 3-19). Furthermore, a difference of five units of Shore A hardness isn’t a significant difference. For example, a rubber band has a Shore A hardness of approximately 20 and a pencil eraser has a Shore A hardness of approximately 40.

uscom:LI.com:U: rejected under 35 U.S.C. 103 as being unpatentable over

uscom:GeneralText.com:U: Schaeper (alternatively in view of Yenulis) in view of Carbaugh et al. (US 2014/0183381)

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Regarding claims 9 and 16, Schaeper discloses a BOP as previously discussed, but is silent with regard to the specific material of the softer material section, including whether the softer material section comprises a polymer comprising at least one of polyether ether ketone (PEEK), polyethylene terephthalate (PET), polyamide, polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA), polyamide-imide, acrylonitrile-methyl acrylate copolymer, cellulose acetate, polyvinyl fluoride, amorphous nylon, polybutylene terephathalate, polyethylene naphthalate, polyimide, polyacetal, acrylonitrile butadiene styrene copolymer (ABS), ethylene chlorotrifluoroethylene copolymer (ECTFE), polyvinylidene fluoride, polyether sulfone, polyetherimide, polycarbonate and high heat polycarbonate, polybenzimidazole, polyphenylene sulfide, ethylene vinyl alcohol copolymer (EVOH), cycloolefin polymer, cycloolefin copolymer, aromatic fluorine-containing polyarylates ionomer, phenolic resin, epoxy, and polyurethane. Carbaugh teaches in Figs. 1-5 a similar BOP comprising a resilient material 16 that is designed to seal against an object passing through the housing like the softer material section disclosed by Schaeper, wherein the resilient material 16 comprises polyamide making up a reinforcing fiber 38 to prevent extrusion of the resilient material when it closes against the object (paragraph 7).

Therefore, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to modify the softer material section in Schaeper (alternatively modified in view of Yenulis) to comprise a polyamide as a reinforcing fiber that prevents extrusion of the softer material section in the closed position, as Carbaugh teaches (paragraph 7)

uscom:LI.com:U: rejected under 35 U.S.C. 103 as being unpatentable over

uscom:GeneralText.com:U: LeRouax in view of Yenulis et al. (US 5,224,557)

uscom:DataField.uscom:GeneralText: Regarding claims 1, 4-5, 11, 13, and 18-21, LeRouax is seen as disclosing all of the limitations positively claimed, however, if the “rubber or other suitable resilient material” forming the body 61 (col. 5, lines 67-68) isn’t seen as disclosing elastomeric, Yenulis teaches in Figs. 1-6 a BOP with a similar packer assembly comprising several nested resilient members 32, 38, 57 that are all elastomeric (col. 4, lines 42 and 52-53, and col. 5, line 44).

uscom:OL.uscom:LI: Therefore, it would have been obvious to one having ordinary skill in the art before the effective filing date of the claimed invention to make the body in LeRouax out of an elastomeric material, as Yenulis teaches with similar resilient members 32, 38, given that LeRouax is silent with regard to such detail. Furthermore, one having ordinary skill in the art would recognize that elastomers include rubber and other resilient materials, like LeRouax discloses (col. 5, lines 67-68), and are readily available and provide the resilience necessary for the body.
